Topic.Title: Mayer's memo...

Message.Msg: "Too bad that her decision was frowned upon on this board and around the nation..." Thankfully, YAHOO! is not run but the opinion of vocal folks around the nation, but by business professionals. I've interviewed young people for professional positions, and they tell me their terms for acepting the position, like "I need time off Tuesday and Thursday at 3 pm for my yoga class, and I don't work more than 40 hours a week - ever". We have a divide in the nation between dedicated and focused employees, and those brought up being told they are all "special" and "deserve praise on a daily basis". If your boss decides working in the office is a job requirement, you have the choice to quit. Working from home is not a right - working for the productivity of the company is a responsibility. So those around the nation offering their opinion of YAHOO! productivity practices can stuff it. Chances are they're still living in the basement of their parents.

Message.Title: Next Bold MM YAHOO! Move!
Message.Msg: Before the Alibaba IPO, YAHOO! shareholders and employees alike would profit at least $2 a share with the next bold move - literally. Leave Sunnyvale, CA and move headquarters to the Austin, TX area. Why? Texas taxes. No state income tax and a lower business tax. Hello lower cost of living, cleaner air, and healthy business climate.

Topic.Title: Mayer's memo...

Message.Msg: Regarding JCP, these were workers at head office - not work-at-home. My point re JCP related to Mayer coming into a situation where to some extent, the inmates were running the asylum. Yes I think the amount of Youtubes downloaded, alone, shows that a proper system of oversight was not in place. Mayer would have also inherited serious issues within Yahoo!. Too many changes at the top over the last 5 years or so have left employees demoralized and without leadership. This leads to much chaos. What do you suggest should be done in a case such as this? No blanket statements on my part regarding an individuals capabiliites to self-govern. Some will be more than capable and others not. It's been quoted throughout the press this week that many, not all, home workers were very much abusing the system - which again was either poorly set-up or poorly executed. I believe this is the first step in combatting an issue that has become unmanageable as is. The next step will be to turf those in head office that allowed the abuses of the system.

Message.Msg: Lucky for her she can build a "nursary" next to her office so she does not have to worry about many of the challanges most of her employees do with repect to child care ..........work at home is a win-win for the company and the employees and even for our society. The old days of having a stay at home parent have pretty much been desimated by the need for dual incomes to provide a middle class std of living. OUr society has taken a hit as many of our children do not have the benefit of parental involvement in their lives as generations before have. Topic.Title: Mayer's memo...

Message.Msg: You are confusing issues. Where both parties are in acceptance, working at home is fine. The CEO of a company that is in desperate need of a turn-around, has identified a problem within this work-at home group. Period. The CEO has decided that the best course of action is to require all to work from headquarters. The CEO is aware that this will cause some of workers in question to quit. The CEO considers this a bonus. Not unlike requiring engineers to up their mobile skills or leave. The CEO will monitor those that do return, to determine if they are still an appropriate fit for Yahoo!'s new direction. I don't see where this is an issue for the general public? Did I miss the memo where Mayer was put in charge of policy for the Dept. of Labor?

Topic.Title: Mayer's memo...

Message.Msg: "...living in the basement of their parents."?? I don't know about that, but we all know how noodling around in your college dorm room (Brin, Zuckerberg, etc.) or in your garage (Hewlett and Packard) never leads anywhere! My point is that the bulls on this board seem unable to differentiate creating from working. Creativity yields significant, episodic value growth; regular work, not so much. The "work"force of Yahoo hasn't yielded much in the last five years to the company's market capitalization. Google's creative force, well that's a different story. Pity MM didn't learn her lessons well.
